intro: Mattiastrum cappadocicum, commonly known as the Cappadocian spurge, is a flowering plant native to the Mediterranean region. It belongs to the Euphorbiaceae family and is characterized by its erect, branched stems and opposite leaves. The plant produces small, inconspicuous yellowish flowers clustered in cyathia, which are typical of the genus. It thrives in well-drained soils and is often found in rocky or dry habitats. Mattiastrum cappadocicum is typically herbaceous, with a short lifespan and is sometimes considered a weed in agricultural settings.
